It's also not the amount drunk that defines addiction. Addiction can be defined as experiencing cravings, having withdrawal symptoms, persisting despite negative consequences, etc etc. The actual criteria for entering into 'addiction' is something only a professional could diagnose you with.
These are 11 criteria that get examined when seeing a psychologist/psychiatrist/professional for susbtance abuse:
1. Taking the substance in larger amounts or for longer than the you meant to
2. Wanting to cut down or stop using the substance but not managing to 3. Spending a lot of time getting, using, or recovering from use of the substance 4. Cravings and urges to use the substance 5. Not managing to do what you should at work, home or school, because of substance use 6. Continuing to use, even when it causes problems in relationships 7. Giving up important social, occupational or recreational activities because of substance use 8. Using substances again and again, even when it puts the you in danger 9. Continuing to use, even when the you know you have a physical or psychological problem that could have been caused or made worse by the substance 10. Needing more of the substance to get the effect you want (tolerance) 11. Development of withdrawal symptoms, which can be relieved by taking more of the substance.
Of course, this was not meant for you to self-diagnose or self-undiagnose. It's just information that is out there.

I really enjoyed rehab. I was in an inpatient facility for 35 days.
Pros
- time away from my regular life
- gave my family time to themselves
- met lots of people in recovery
- had no outside distractions: no dishes, no meal preparation, nothing. just recovery, homework, meetings, chatting to nurses, doctors and social workers and other recovering people
- very supportive. I was constantly surrounded by people who wanted to help me and listen.
- an extremely thought out and researched treatment plan. My team consisted of a social worker, an addiction doctor (yes they exist), a psychologist and an addiction counsellor. They had team meetings every day to discuss everyone's progress.
Cons
- travel time to get there was 7 hour car ride
